questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with transient right-sided weakness. Evaluation reveals a small ischemic stroke and a patent foramen ovale (PFO) with right-to-left shunt. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Aspirin : Antiplatelet therapy alone is less effective than PFO closure in preventing recurrent stroke.
  • • Option A. Aspirin
  • • Option C. Warfarin : Anticoagulation may be considered in older patients or those with contraindications to PFO closure.
  • • Option C. Warfarin
  • • Option D. Observation : Not appropriate due to the high risk of recurrent stroke in this scenario.
  • • Option D. Observation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ PFO closure is recommended for younger patients (< 60y) with cryptogenic stroke and PFO to reduce the risk of recurrent stroke.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with progressive dyspnea, a systolic murmur at the left second intercostal space, a diastolic flow rumble over the tricuspid valve, and fixed splitting of the second heart sound (S2). ECG is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: B
options.text: Bicuspid aortic valve with aortic regurgitation

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option B. Bicuspid aortic valve with AR : Would have a diastolic murmur at the left sternal border.
  • • Option B. Bicuspid aortic valve with AR
  • • Option C. Mitral stenosis : Would have a diastolic murmur at the apex.
  • • Option C. Mitral stenosis
  • • Option D. VSD : Typically presents with a holosystolic murmur.
  • • Option D. VSD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Recognize the clinical and ECG findings suggestive of an ASD.
  • ➤ as amyloidosis, should be considered. Serum protein electrophoresis/urine protein electrophoresis and free light-chain analysis may help identify immunoglobulin light-chain amyloidosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is evaluated for exertional dyspnea. On physical examination, a parasternal impulse is noted at the left sternal border. A grade 2/6 systolic murmur is heard at the second left intercostal space with fixed splitting of the S2. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: B. Ostium secundum atrial septal defect
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents with palpitations and syncope. On examination, he has a systolic click with a pansystolic murmur in the left lower sternal border and an elevated JVP. He also complains of intermittent bluish discoloration of face during exercise since childhood. ECG is shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. ASD: While ASD can be present in Ebstein's anomaly, it alone does not explain all the clinical features in this case.
  • • Option
  • • A. ASD:
  • • Option B. VSD: VSD presents with a harsh holosystolic murmur but not the other findings in this case.
  • • Option
  • • B. VSD:
  • • Option D. TOF: TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart defect with a different murmur pattern (harsh systolic ejection murmur) and ECG findings.
  • • Option D. TOF:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Very tall (Himalayan) P waves are a hallmark of Ebstein’s anomaly.

questions.text: You are in the emergency department when a 19-year-old woman, Ms. Vidhya, arrives after collapsing during a Sunday marathon. She is unresponsive and pulseless. ECG is shown. Which of the following rhythms is the cause of her cardiac arrest?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia: This is usually a narrow-complex tachycardia, unlike the wide-complex seen in this case.
  • • Option B. Atrioventricular nodal reentrant tachycardia:
  • • Option C. Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia: This has a regular rhythm with similar QRS complexes, unlike the irregular pattern seen here.
  • • Option C. Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia:
  • • Option D. Torsades de pointes: Difficult to differentiate but the given ECG does not have the twisting morphology to consider it as Torsades de pointes.
  • • Option D. Torsades de pointes:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ AF with preexcitation presents with rapid irregular wide-complex tachycardia and it is lethal.

questions.text: Ms. Kavitha, a 22-year-old woman with rheumatic mitral stenosis develops atrial fibrillation. Her CHA₂DS₂-VASc is 1. Which of the following is the correct approach to stroke prevention?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. No anticoagulation: Incorrect, since AF increases the risk of stroke by 20-25x in patients with mitral stenosis.
  • • Option A. No anticoagulation:
  • • Option C. Initiate aspirin 325 mg daily: Insufficient for stroke prevention in patients with AF and high risk factors like rheumatic mitral stenosis.
  • • Option C. Initiate aspirin 325 mg daily:
  • • Option D. Initiate apixaban 5 mg twice daily: DOACs are not recommended in patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis due to limited data.
  • • Option D. Initiate apixaban 5 mg twice daily:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant for stroke prevention in patients with AF and rheumatic mitral stenosis.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents with exertional dyspnea, and chest pain. Echo was done and showed severe aortic stenosis, He has hypertension, chronic kidney disease (stage G4), hyperlipidemia, severe COPD, and atrial fibrillation. What is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transcatheter aortic valve implantation is recommended in preference to surgical aortic valve replacement for symptomatic patients with severe aortic stenosis who are older than 80 years or younger patients with a life expectancy less than 10 years.
  • ➤ Transcatheter aortic valve implantation is recommended for symptomatic patients of any age with severe aortic stenosis and a high or prohibitive surgical risk if predicted post procedure survival is more than 12 months with an acceptable quality of life.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with fatigue and near-syncope with exertion. He has a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur along the right upper sternal border that increases with squatting. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM): The murmur of HCM is typically heard best at the left lower sternal border and decreases with squatting.
  • • Option B. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM):
  • • Option C. Restrictive membranous ventricular septal defect (VSD): VSDs typically present with a holosystolic murmur, not a systolic ejection murmur.
  • • Option C. Restrictive membranous ventricular septal defect (VSD):
  • • Option D. Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm: This typically presents with a continuous murmur.
  • • Option D. Ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Systolic ejection murmur along the right upper sternal border that increases with squatting as a classic finding of a bicuspid aortic valve.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man presents with a 3 hour history of chest pain. His BP is 80/50 mmHg, HR is 120/min and has elevated JVP and clear lungs. ECG is shown. What is the most appropriate treatment ?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Intra-aortic balloon pump placement: Indicated in cardiogenic shock with LV dysfunction, but not the first-line treatment for RV infarction.
  • • Option A. Intra-aortic balloon pump placement:
  • • Option B. Intravenous dobutamine: Inotrope may be considered if fluids are ineffective, but not the initial management.
  • • Option B. Intravenous dobutamine:
  • • Option D. Oral metoprolol: Beta-blockers can worsen hypotension and should be avoided in RV infarction.
  • • Option D. Oral metoprolol:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A patient with an inferior myocardial infarction with right ventricular involvement and hypotension should receive intravenous fluids.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with atrial fibrillation and severe primary mitral regurgitation (MR) due to mitral valve prolapse has an LVEF of 55% and LV end-systolic dimension of 60 mm. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI): Unnecessary if the mechanism and severity of MR are already established by TTE.
  • • Option A. Cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI):
  • • Option C. Transcatheter mitral valve repair (TMVR): Considered in patients with favourable anatomy and high risk for surgical repair.
  • • Option C. Transcatheter mitral valve repair (TMVR):
  • • Option D. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE): May be helpful if TTE is inconclusive, but not necessary in this case.
  • • Option D. Transesophageal echocardiography (TEE):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Surgery for chronic primary severe mitral regurgitation is indicated in the presence of symptoms, left ventricular dilation, or reduced ejection fraction.
  • ➤ Surgical mitral valve repair is first-line therapy for patients with primary severe mitral regurgitation meeting indications for intervention.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a mechanical mitral valve prosthesis is planning pregnancy. She is currently on warfarin 4mg with a stable INR of 3.0. What is the most appropriate anticoagulation strategy during the first trimester?

options.label: C
options.text: Stop warfarin and start subcutaneous dose-adjusted unfractionated heparin (UFH)

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Stop warfarin and start Bivalirudin: Not recommended for long-term anticoagulation in pregnancy.
  • • Option A. Stop warfarin and start Bivalirudin:
  • • Option B. Stop warfarin and start Dabigatran : Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) are not recommended in pregnancy due to limited safety data.
  • • Option B. Stop warfarin and start Dabigatran
  • • Option C. Stop warfarin and start subcutaneous dose-adjusted unfractionated heparin UFH: Can be considered if warfarin dose is >5 mg/d or if the patient prefers to avoid warfarin during the first trimester.
  • • Option C. Stop warfarin and start subcutaneous dose-adjusted unfractionated heparin
  • • UFH:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant for pregnant women with mechanical heart valves if the dose is ≤5 mg/d.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presents with exertional dyspnea and elevated BNP. 2D Echo shows EF of 45% and low-flow, low-gradient severe aortic stenosis. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Cardiac catheterization: In this patient who likely has low cardiac output, direct measurement of the aortic valve gradient by cardiac catheterization (Option A) would result in low gradients that underestimate the severity of the AS, similar to gradient and velocity values on resting echocardiography. Dobutamine catheterization may be performed in lieu of dobutamine echocardiography in this case.
  • • Option A. Cardiac catheterization:
  • • Option C. & option D. Surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR) or Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI): Proceeding to surgical or transcatheter aortic valve implantation is inappropriate at this time; the resting echo does not adequately differentiate between pseudosevere AS due to insufficient stroke volume and low-flow, low-gradient severe AS.
  • • Option C. & option D.
  • • Surgical aortic valve replacement (SAVR) or Transcatheter aortic valve implantation (TAVI):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diagnose low-flow, low-gradient severe symptomatic aortic stenosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man had a mechanical mitral valve replacement 1 year ago. He is currently on warfarin and his INR is 3.4. He now presents with easy bruising and scattered ecchymoses. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Decreasing warfarin dosage: Would increase the risk of thromboembolic events.
  • • Option B. Decreasing warfarin dosage:
  • • Option C. Discontinue warfarin and start aspirin: Not sufficient for anticoagulation in patients with mechanical valves.
  • • Option C. Discontinue warfarin and start aspirin:
  • • Option D. Discontinue warfarin and start dabigatran : DOACs are not recommended for patients with mechanical valves (based on the data from Re-ALIGN trial).
  • • Option D. Discontinue warfarin and start dabigatran

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with a prosthetic cardiac valve, the appropriate INR goal varies by type of valve and valve position, with a goal INR of 3.0 (range 2.5-3.5) for a mechanical valve in the mitral position. Dabigatran is associated with excess bleeding and thrombosis, and the safety of other direct oral anticoagulants has not been assessed.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman is evaluated for an 18-month history of progressive fatigue and dyspnea. Blood pressure is 112/72 mm Hg, pulse rate is 76/min, and respiration rate is normal. The apical impulse is slightly sustained but not displaced. Auscultation is performed at the cardiac apex. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Aortic regurgitation: Aortic regurgitation produces a high-pitched diastolic murmur heard best along the mid left sternal border.
  • • Option A. Aortic regurgitation:
  • • Option B. Mitral regurgitation: Mitral regurgitation produces a high-pitched holosystolic murmur loudest at the cardiac apex.
  • • Option B. Mitral regurgitation:
  • • Option D. Pulmonic regurgitation: The murmur of pulmonic regurgitation is early diastolic, best heard over the left second and third interspaces and increases in intensity with inspiration.
  • • Option D. Pulmonic regurgitation:

questions.text: A 75-year-old patient with long-standing atrial fibrillation (AF) received a VVIR pacemaker. After a few months, he presents with dizziness, fatigue, and visible pulsations in the neck. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Sick sinus syndrome: Would not be associated with elevated JVP or cannon ‘a’ waves.
  • • Option A. Sick sinus syndrome:
  • • Option C. Lead displacement: Lead displacement would likely cause pacing failure or erratic pacing, not the specific symptoms described.
  • • Option C. Lead displacement:
  • • Option D. Ventricular tachycardia: This would present with a rapid, regular heart rhythm and different symptoms (palpitations, chest pain, syncope).
  • • Option D. Ventricular tachycardia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pacemaker syndrome is a potential complication of single-chamber ventricular pacing (usually VVIR), and presents with dizziness and syncope due to AV dissociation.

questions.text: What is the most common mechanism of digitalis-induced ventricular arrhythmias?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Re-entry: While re-entry is the most common mechanism for arrhythmias in general, it's not the primary mechanism for digitalis-induced ventricular arrhythmias.
  • • Option A. Re-entry:
  • • Option C. Early afterdepolarizations (EADs): EADs are associated with prolonged repolarization (long QT syndrome), which is not a direct effect of digitalis toxicity.
  • • Option C. Early afterdepolarizations (EADs):
  • • Option D. Enhanced automaticity: Although digitalis can increase automaticity, it's not the predominant mechanism; DADs caused by calcium overload play a more significant role.
  • • Option D. Enhanced automaticity:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understand that the primary mechanism of digitalis-induced ventricular arrhythmias is delayed afterdepolarizations (DADs) caused by intracellular calcium overload.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the AV node accurately?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Sodium-dependent conduction: The action potential upstroke in the AV node is dependent on the smaller and slower inward Ca2+ current, which is the reason why the upstroke velocity of the action potential is low—one of the factors responsible for the slow conduction velocity in the AV node.
  • • Option B. Sodium-dependent conduction:
  • • Option C. Increased gap junctions: The AV node actually has fewer gap junctions than other parts of the conduction system, contributing to its slower conduction speed.
  • • Option C. Increased gap junctions:
  • • Option D. Speed of conduction is 1-2 m/s: The conduction speed in the AV node is much slower, around 0.05 m/s (50 mm/s).
  • • Option D. Speed of conduction is 1-2 m/s:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ AV node acts as a ‘gatekeeper’ to the ventricles.

questions.text: You are seeing Mr. Aravind, a 24-year-old previously healthy athlete, for his routine physical examination. Which of the following rhythms is demonstrated?

options.label: B
options.text: Mobitz type I, second-degree heart block

options.label: C
options.text: Mobitz type II, second-degree heart block

questions.correct_answer: B. Mobitz type I, second-degree heart block
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. First-degree heart block: This has a prolonged but constant PR interval.
  • • Option A. First-degree heart block:
  • • Option C. Mobitz type II, second-degree heart block: This has a constant PR interval with occasional dropped QRS complexes.
  • • Option C. Mobitz type II, second-degree heart block:
  • • Option D. Type III heart block (complete heart block): This has complete dissociation between the atria and ventricles, with no relationship between P waves and QRS complexes.
  • • Option D. Type III heart block (complete heart block):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mobitz type I second-degree heart block (Wenckebach) is a relatively benign rhythm often seen in athletes due to high vagal tone.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT indicative of high risk in Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome?

options.label: D
options.text: Accessory pathway in the posteroseptal region

questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Multiple pathways: The presence of multiple accessory pathways increases the risk of arrhythmias and is a high-risk feature.
  • • Option A. Multiple pathways:
  • • Option C. Inducible AF or AVRT: The ability to induce AF or AV reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) during electrophysiology study indicates a higher risk of spontaneous arrhythmias and is a high-risk feature.
  • • Option C. Inducible AF or AVRT:
  • • Option D. Accessory pathway in the posteroseptal region: Poster septal accessory pathways are associated with a higher risk of sudden cardiac death due to their potential to conduct rapidly during AF.
  • • Option D. Accessory pathway in the posteroseptal region:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ High risk in WPW = multiple accessory pathways, accessory pathway refractory period < 240ms, inducible AVRT or AF in EPS & shortest RR in AF ≤ 250ms.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the most common form of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT)?

options.label: B
options.text: It relies on enhanced automaticity as a mechanism.

options.label: C
options.text: It relies on multiple pathways for conduction from the atrium into the AV node.

options.label: D
options.text: It requires systemic anticoagulation for thromboembolic prophylaxis.

questions.correct_answer: C. It relies on multiple pathways for conduction from the atrium into the AV node.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. It is usually life-threatening: AVNRT is usually not life-threatening, though it can cause significant symptoms.
  • • Option A. It is usually life-threatening:
  • • Option B. It relies on enhanced automaticity as a mechanism: AVNRT is a re-entry tachycardia, not caused by enhanced automaticity.
  • • Option B. It relies on enhanced automaticity as a mechanism:
  • • Option D. It requires systemic anticoagulation for thromboembolic prophylaxis: Anticoagulation is not typically required for AVNRT unless there are additional risk factors for thromboembolism.
  • • Option D. It requires systemic anticoagulation for thromboembolic prophylaxis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common form of PSVT is AVNRT, which is caused by re-entry circuits involving multiple pathways within the AV node.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of pacemaker insertion presents to you for routine review. You notice the pacemaker site like what is shown in the image. What is the most appropriate additional management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Aspiration: Not recommended for diagnostic purposes and can worsen infection.
  • • Option A. Aspiration:
  • • Option C. Topical mupirocin: Ineffective for deep pocket infection.
  • • Option C. Topical mupirocin:
  • • Option D. Observation: Inappropriate as the infection can worsen and lead to serious complications.
  • • Option D. Observation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prompt device removal and antibiotic therapy is required in cases of suspected or confirmed cardiac device infection.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with recurrent syncope without prodrome. His father died suddenly at age 45. ECG is shown. Physical examination and 2D Echo is normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. Coronary artery disease: Unlikely in a young patient with no risk factors and normal ECG findings.
  • • Option B. Coronary artery disease:
  • • Option C. Long QT syndrome: ECG would show a prolonged QT interval, not the Brugada pattern.
  • • Option C. Long QT syndrome:
  • • Option D. Vasovagal syncope: Typically has prodromal symptoms (lightheadedness, nausea) and normal ECG.
  • • Option D. Vasovagal syncope:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiovascular syncopal events often occur suddenly and usually without a significant prodrome, although chest pain and palpitations may be present.
  • ➤ Causes of cardiovascular syncope include cardiac arrhythmia; coronary artery disease; and structural and obstructive disease, including aortic and pulmonary valve stenosis, obstructive hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, aortic dissection, and cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: A 76-year-old woman presents with palpitations. Her ECG is shown. She is a known diabetic and hypertensive and currently taking metformin and metoprolol. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Aspirin: Insufficient for stroke prevention in high-risk patients.
  • • Option A. Aspirin:
  • • Option B. Increase metoprolol dosage: Not necessary as the ventricular rate is controlled.
  • • Option B. Increase metoprolol dosage:
  • • Option D. Reassurance: Inappropriate as the patient is at high risk for stroke.
  • • Option D. Reassurance:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In stable patients with atrial fibrillation, the primary goals of therapy are to (1) prevent stroke, (2) control heart rate, (3) minimize or eliminate symptoms, and (4) modify underlying risk factors.
  • ➤ Anticoagulation is indicated for stroke prevention in patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation who have a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or greater in men or 3 or greater in women.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with palpitations and lightheadedness. He was having significant work pressure over the last 2 weeks and he has not been sleeping well. ECG showed VT and he is successfully cardioverted in the ER. Echocardiogram is normal. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.correct_answer: A. Cardiac MRI with stress perfusion
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. EP study: May be indicated later if diagnosis of sustained VT is in doubt or if ablation is being considered (to localize the arrhythmogenic focus).
  • • Option B. EP study:
  • • Option C. ICD: May be considered if there is VT + structural heart disease or HF with EF ≤ 35%. In idiopathic VT, it is unnecessary.
  • • Option C. ICD:
  • • Option D. ILR: It would be premature to consider ILR placement before assessment for structural heart disease. An ILR may be valuable to assess rare recurrences of arrhythmia and/or to assess symptoms, but further evaluation is needed first.
  • • Option D. ILR:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardiac MRI with stress perfusion is a valuable tool for evaluating the underlying cause of VT in patients with structurally normal hearts on echocardiography.

questions.text: An 81-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for chest pain. During the evaluation, he becomes unresponsive and pulseless. ECG is shown. what is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient is in ventricular fibrillation. Immediate defibrillation is required and treatment should proceed along advanced cardiac life support protocol. Defibrillation in this case should precede administration of oxygen. Medications will not be effective in the absence of circulation.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman is evaluated for episodes of palpitations. ECG is shown. Which of the following abnormalities or underlying conditions is responsible for the changes on this patient's ECG?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 57-year-old woman with peripheral artery disease is evaluated prior to elective cholecystectomy. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely electrocardiographic diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely cause of the findings on this electrocardiogram?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman experiences intermittent palpitations, shortness of breath, and light headedness. ECG is shown. Echocardiogram is normal. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Options A. Atenolol and D. Verapamil (AV nodal blockers): These medications are atrioventricular nodal blockers and may be unsafe if the patient has anterograde conduction down the accessory pathway during atrial fibrillation. These drugs promote rapid 1:1 conduction from the atria to the ventricles over the accessory pathway during atrial fibrillation, which can lead to very rapid ventricular rates and ventricular fibrillation.
  • • Options A. Atenolol and D. Verapamil (AV nodal blockers):
  • • Option C. Flecainide: It is an antiarrhythmic drug that is frequently used to treat paroxysmal atrial fibrillation and other arrhythmias. Flecainide is not indicated in this patient because the type and mechanism of the arrhythmia are unknown. This patient requires risk stratification, which can be accomplished with an electrophysiology study.
  • • Option C. Flecainide:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ In patients with suspected WPW syndrome, an EP study is indicated to assess arrhythmia risk and consider ablation of the accessory pathway.

questions.text: An 81-year-old man with a history of hypertension and osteoarthritis is scheduled for elective hip arthroplasty. He is asymptomatic and has no history of cardiovascular disease. His ECG is shown. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.correct_answer: D. No further testing or intervention
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • :
  • • Option A. Dobutamine echocardiography: Not indicated as there are no signs or symptoms of heart failure or ischemia.
  • • Option A. Dobutamine echocardiography:
  • • Option B. Echocardiography: Not necessary as the ECG findings are not suggestive of structural heart disease.
  • • Option B. Echocardiography:
  • • Option C. Prophylactic pacemaker insertion: Not indicated in asymptomatic patients with bifascicular block and first-degree AV block.
  • • Option C. Prophylactic pacemaker insertion:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ :
  • ➤ Asymptomatic Tri-fascicular block does not require pacemaker implantation

questions.text: An 84-year-old man presents with fatigue and loss of energy. His ECG is shown. Upon vigorous exercise his heart rate reaches a maximum of 72/min. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hospital admission: Not necessary unless the patient is hemodynamically unstable.
  • • Option A. Hospital admission:
  • • Option C. Switching medications: Unlikely to address the underlying bradycardia.
  • • Option C. Switching medications:
  • • Option D. Reassurance and monitoring: Inadequate for symptomatic bradycardia with potential for adverse outcomes.
  • • Option D. Reassurance and monitoring:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Treat a patient with symptomatic bradycardia.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man with history of hypertension and stroke has been diagnosed with mildly symptomatic paroxysmal AF. He is currently taking rivaroxaban and metoprolol. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Left atrial appendage occlusion: Indicated for stroke prevention in non-valvular AF but not the primary treatment for rhythm control.
  • • Option A. Left atrial appendage occlusion:
  • • Option B. Pacemaker implantation: Not indicated for paroxysmal AF without symptomatic bradycardia.
  • • Option B. Pacemaker implantation:
  • • Option D. No additional therapy: Early rhythm control is recommended for this patient.
  • • Option D. No additional therapy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with recently diagnosed atrial fibrillation and concomitant cardiovascular conditions, early rhythm control (antiarrhythmic drugs or ablation) reduces the primary composite end point of cardiovascular death, stroke, or hospitalization for heart failure or acute coronary syndrome compared with usual care.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man with hypertension presents with acute shortness of breath, hypotension and palpitations. He has jugular venous distention and pulmonary crackles. ECG was done and is shown below. After successful cardioversion, what is the best treatment?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Amiodarone: Antiarrhythmic drug that can be used for atrial flutter, but catheter ablation is more definitive.
  • • Option A. Amiodarone:
  • • Option C. Flecainide: Another antiarrhythmic drug, but catheter ablation is preferred.
  • • Option C. Flecainide:
  • • Option D. Metoprolol: Beta-blocker, primarily used for rate control, not as effective for rhythm control in atrial flutter.
  • • Option D. Metoprolol:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Catheter ablation is the definitive treatment for typical atrial flutter due to its high success rate and low complication rate.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with recurrent palpitations lasting 5-15 minutes, occue a few times per month and relieved by rest or deep breathing. The resting ECG is normal. What is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Exercise ECG: Not indicated for evaluating palpitations occurring at rest.
  • • Option A. Exercise ECG:
  • • Option B. Implantable loop recorder: Reserved for very infrequent or unexplained syncope (which prevents the patient from triggering the devices). Records symptomatic and asymptomatic events (brady/tachy) over a very long period (months to years).
  • • Option B. Implantable loop recorder:
  • • Option C. Holter monitoring : Usually records electrical activity continuously for 24-28 hours and most suited for patients with more frequent symptoms (e.g., daily).
  • • Option C. Holter monitoring

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A 30-day event monitor is most appropriate for evaluating patients with palpitations who have symptoms that occur less than daily but frequently over the course of a month.
  • ➤ An implantable looping event recorder is most appropriate for infrequent or highly symptomatic arrhythmias in which the symptoms might preclude a patient from activating the device, such as syncope.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is evaluated for palpitations. ECG is shown. Which of the following abnormalities is demonstrated on this patient's ECG?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man is evaluated for symptoms of dyspnea, peripheral edema, and exercise intolerance. Echocardiography shows biventricular increased wall thickness. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is evaluated for the acute onset of severe chest pain. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A pregnant lady G2P1L1 currently 37 weeks POG (period of gestation) presented with worsening headache, blurring of vision, reduced perception of fetal movements. On arrival, BP was 200/100 mmHg. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the best management?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. IV lignocaine: While lidocaine is an antiarrhythmic, it is not effective in PMVT.
  • • Option B. IV lignocaine:
  • • Option C. IV amiodarone: Amiodarone is effective for monomorphic VT but can prolong QTc interval and potentially can trigger PMVT.
  • • Option C. IV amiodarone:
  • • Option D. Defibrillation: Can be tried in case of unstable PMVT or if the patient is in cardiac arrest.
  • • Option D. Defibrillation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IV MgSO4 is the treatment of choice for stable PMVT.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is evaluated for palpations and light headedness. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with sarcoidosis is evaluated for an irregular pulse, a sensation of pounding in the neck, and an episode of syncope. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman is evaluated for unexplained right heart enlargement and a history of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. Physical examination reveals a parasternal impulse, fixed splitting of S2, mitral regurgitation, and a pulmonary outflow murmur. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Ostium primum atrial septal defect
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 64-year-old woman is evaluated in the emergency department following an episode of syncope. ECG is shown. Which of the following abnormalities is demonstrated on this patient's ECG?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is evaluated in the emergency department for rapid heart rate and dizziness. He was recently started on levofloxacin for community-acquired pneumonia. A telemetry rhythm strip is shown. Which of the following abnormalities is seen on this patient's telemetry rhythm strip?

options.label: B
options.text: Right bundle branch block with aberrancy

questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is evaluated for recurrent episodes of syncope. She is otherwise well and takes no medications. ECG is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 79-year-old woman is evaluated for fatigue and bradycardia. ECG is shown. Which of the following abnormalities is seen on this patient's ECG?
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a recent type B aortic dissection presents with abdominal pain and lower limb ischemia with diminished femoral and popliteal pulses. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Repair the descending aorta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Enalaprilat: Although used for blood pressure control, it doesn't address the underlying issue of malperfusion.
  • • Option A. Enalaprilat:
  • • Option B. Increasing nitroprusside: May help with blood pressure control but doesn't solve the urgent need for revascularization.
  • • Option B. Increasing nitroprusside:
  • • Option D. Switching to amlodipine: Not appropriate in an acute setting requiring immediate intervention.
  • • Option D. Switching to amlodipine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Recognize the signs of complicated type B aortic dissection (malperfusion syndromes) and the need for immediate surgical/endovascular repair.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with Marfan syndrome has an ascending aortic diameter of 4.3 cm, which has increased by 0.6 cm in the past year. Her mother had an aortic dissection. She is considering pregnancy. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Aortic repair before pregnancy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Atorvastatin: Statins are not indicated for aortic disease management in this context and are contraindicated in pregnancy.
  • • Option A. Atorvastatin:
  • • Option B. Losartan: Contraindicated in pregnancy due to fetal toxicity.
  • • Option B. Losartan:
  • • Option D. Proceeding with pregnancy without aortic repair would be dangerous due to the high risk of dissection.
  • • Option D.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with Marfan syndrome have an increased risk for pregnancy-related aortic dissection and rupture; aortic repair surgery is recommended before conception to reduce this risk in those with an ascending aortic diameter greater than 4.0 cm and who have risk factors for aortic dissection.

questions.text: A 73-year-old woman with extensive cardiovascular disease and poorly controlled hypertension is evaluated for acute-onset ripping chest pain that radiates to her back. Chest radiograph is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The most likely diagnosis is acute aortic dissection. This patient's chest radiograph shows a widened superior mediastinum and a right pleural effusion consistent with aortic dissection, although these findings are not diagnostic. The diagnosis of aortic dissection can be established with transesophageal echocardiography, CT angiography, or MR angiography, all of which have similar sensitivity and specificity for acute thoracic aortic disease. Because of its wide availability and short image acquisition time, CT angiography has become the primary diagnostic test for acute thoracic aortic disease.

questions.text: Which of the following disorders could account for the findings on the rhythm strip of a homeless man who was found unresponsive on the street?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hypothermia most likely accounts for the findings shown on this electrocardiogram. In hypothermia, all of the electrocardiographic intervals are prolonged, including the PR interval, the QRS complex, the QT interval, and the R-R interval, owing to slowed impulse conduction through potassium channels. In addition, the J point is elevated, producing a characteristic J wave (Osborn wave) that represents distortion of the earliest phase of membrane repolarization. These changes are most prominent in the precordial leads V2 through V5. This electrocardiogram demonstrates Osborn waves (arrows).

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is demonstrated on this electrocardiogram?
questions.explanation: Ans.
